story: IT WAS a day to remember for one couple, reported the East Lothian Courier of January , .The parents of  children and  grandchildren have celebrated making it to their th wedding anniversary... after the bridersquos mother told them when they got married: ldquoIrsquoll give it a year.Jozef Rybak, , and his we Davina, , of Herdmanflatt, Haddington, proved her mother wrong when they were joined by their family and  friends to enjoy their golden wedding anniversary in the Labour Club, Haddington.Although Davinarsquos mother had initial doubts over her daughter marrying a Polish soldier, her views mellowed and she developed a strong relationship with Jozef.Jozef and Davina met at a dance in Haddington Town House in , when he was stationed in the town.Davina described how her first meeting with her future husband was not as romantic as she would have hoped for: ldquoI wanted to run like hell because he couldnrsquot dance. He started jumping about and I had to teach him how to dance.A BID to attract more Swedish visitors to Dunbar was reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier on January , .The Americans are no longer the most attractive type of tourist ndash at least not in the eyes of certain Dunbar hoteliers.At a meeting held on Monday to discuss the possibilities of package holidays to extend the season, it was apparent their sights were most definitely set on Scandinavia.The Yank of today, it seems, is not so prone to spending as was his camera-festooned dollar-spreading predecessor of  years ago.So local hoteliers are out to charm the Swedish student who at home has to pay s for his pint and s for his ldquodram. At the meeting, a scheme aimed at attracting students from Sweden was outlined.A HOTEL owner ldquofoolishly yielded to a request from a customer for a pint of whisky, told The Haddingtonshire Courier of January , .In Haddington Sherf Court, on Monday, before Sherf Macleod, Alexander D. Laing, hotel-keeper, Railway Hotel, Haddington, was charged with having, on Saturday, th instant, sold to John Patterson, draper, Hope Park, Haddington, whisky of less measure than a quart, and in a bottle which did not bear a label containing the name and situation of the licensed premises.Mr Patterson, a most respectable citizen, entered the hotel, and represented that he was suffering from heart trouble. He askedhe could be supplied with a pint of whisky, and, as he was a gentleman who was well known, Mr Laing foolishly yielded to the request.

title: zans-wildlife-diary-intriguing-roe-deer
story: I hope you all had a lovely festive break and enjoyed the recent snow falls. I must say that I loved it and I wish for Musselburgh to get a bit more of this beautul snowy coverage over the upcoming days.There is nothing more exciting than watching all the little birds hopping around on the snow!Some of you may have started this month by writing your New Yearrsquos resolutions and so did I.Unlike the usual list of everyday le goals, mine relates to wildle species I would like to photograph this year.You may be surprised but top of my list is the roe deer. Yes, that is right, the roe deer ndash one of the most common animals in East Lothian, which occasionally visits your gardenyou stay on the outskirts of built-up areas.I have seen and photographed roe deer on many occasions however, this year I would like to focus on this species in a bit more depth and produce a portfolio that illustrates this animal in dferent seasons.What is so intriguing about the roe deer is their behaviour and appearance both changing throughout the year.I am totally fascinated by deer antlers which, unlike horns, are shed and regrown each year.Roe deer males develop relatively short antlers which begin to grow in November and are covered in fur, called lsquovelvetrsquo, for the first few months.Velvet is a special type of skin, which is packed withblood vesselsand nerves to supply the antlers with necessary nutrients.The blood flow in the velvet is crucial in sustaining the healthy antlers should the velvet get prematurely damaged, the antlers can become deformed.In spring, when the growth of the antlers is complete, thevelvetis rubbed offand the bucks are ready for the breeding season, or rut.The rutting season of the roe deer occurs between mid-July and mid-August.During this time, bucks will use their antlers to fight with neighbouring males to take over their territories and the femalesthat visit that area. Fights between males can be violent and sometimes lead to serious injury or death.No matter how tempting it is for a photographer to capture battling deer, it is also incredibly dangerous to come anywhere near these animals during their breeding season.At this time of the year, bucks are aggressive and can pose a danger to human le.It is important not to approach these animals but to watch them from the distance and safety of a vehicle.It is also important not to disturb them at this crucial point in time.In this season, it is vital for deer to be able to showcase their natural behaviour without any disturbance.Aftermating, bucks shed their antlers in October and begin to grow a new set.Young roe deerare born in May and June and stay with their mothers for about  months.This year, I would be particularly delighted to capture fawns on camera as I, like many others, find these animals an appealing subject.Another interesting aspect that I would like to capture in my photos is the colour of the deerrsquos coat, which changes throughout the year.Summer time is when their coat is most distinguishable and turns a bright rusty red colour, while in winter it is dull, almost grey.If you regularly watch roe deer or know their location and could help gather images, I would like to hear from you!Speak to you next month.www.facebook zanslens www.instagram zans_lens www zans_lens

title: holyrood-election-2021-three-candidates-far-midlothian-north-musselburgh
story: Sitting MSP Colin Beattie, SNP, is seeking re-election Labourrsquos choice to fight the seat is Midlothian councillor Stevie Curran and representing the Scottish Conservatives is City of Edinburgh councillor Iain Whyte.The Liberal Democrats said that their selection process was ongoing and the Scottish Greens are not fielding a candidate for the Midlothian North  Musselburgh seat.Mr Beattie said he was ldquoproud to have served the people of Midlothian North and Musselburgh for the past  years.He said: ldquoDuring this time, I have helped so many people in many dferent ways.ldquoThese are not easy times for any of us, with dficult decisions being made for the protection of us all.ldquoThere is no doubt that some decisions have caused real problems for businesses and iniduals ndash but, as Covid- has been spreading rapidly, there has been no alternative.ldquoI have reached out to many businesses across the constituency offering support to protect jobs.He added: ldquoPeople have asked what my priorities would beI was re-elected. Simple: jobs and the economy.ldquoTough times lie ahead and the leading issue must be to reboot our economy and generate new jobs locally, as well as protect existing jobs.He claimed: ldquoThe SNP has made huge progress in building a fairer and more equal society. We must not lose these gains in the drive to compensate for the disaster that is Brexit, which was inexplicably driven through by the Tory Westminster Government during an unprecedented pandemic.ldquoIt is clearer to me than ever before that  years of the Union has neither delivered our potential prosperity nor true democratic accountability.ldquoIndependence will not automatically bring wealth and wellbeing. Independence will allow us to take the critical decisions towards those goals and empower us to build a fairer society.ldquoI hope the residents of Midlothian North  Musselburgh will give me another opportunity to serve them.Mr Curran, , who lives in Dalkeith, is councillor for the Dalkeith and Danderhall ward on Midlothian Council.He has held cabinet responsibility for housing since being elected in  and has ldquoextensive experience working in the public sector, including more than  years with Lothian and Borders Police Police Scotland as an operations co-ordinator. He is also chairman of the Midlothian Police and Fire and Rescue Scrutiny Board. He was selected as the Labour candidate by the Midlothian North and Musselburgh Labour Party.Mr Curran said: ldquoWords canrsquot do justice to the sense of pride I feel to have been afforded the opportunity to represent the constituency where Irsquove lived my entire le.He highlighted his priorities, saying: ldquoExiting the pandemic safely, and the economic recovery from its devastating impact will be a priority for the next Parliament.ldquoOur region is growing rapidly but council funding and transport infrastructure to accommodate our growth is deficient, from the underfunding of the , hours of early learning and childcare to the delayed grade separation at Sherfhall.ldquoAs a councillor, I know all too well the impact of cuts to council budgets, and I will fight tooth and nail for fairer funding for our local authorities.ldquoItrsquos also vital that local issues donrsquot get lost in the recovery from Covid-, and that Covid is not used as an excuse to delay intervention in matters that require urgent attention, one such example being the ongoing issues at [Musselburghrsquos]Riverside Medical Practice.ldquoI will be addressing this very issue, among others, on day one in Parliament as constituency MSP.Mr Whyte represents Inverleith ward on City of Edinburgh Council and is its Conservative Group leader.He has previously served as a non-executive board member of the Scottish Police Authority and NHS Lothian, where he was chairman of the then East Lothian Community Health Partnership.His experience of public services in East Lothian and Midlothian was formed during his time as convener of the Lothian and Borders Police Board, prior to the amalgamation of policing into Police Scotland.He currently serves as a board member of EDI Ltd and as chairman and a founder member of the Edinburgh March Riding Association.Mr Whyte said: ldquoI am looking forward to working with our excellent and hard-working team of Conservative councillors from both Midlothian and East Lothian to get our message over to the public.ldquoAs a councillor who has had a role across the Lothians in the past as the Police Board convenor, and as someone who has been involved in NHS services in these areas, I know that high-quality public services are important to people.ldquoI want to take the fight straight to the SNP in this seat, as their record shows they have let things slip on key issues like education and health, while they have underfunded our police and councils.

title: roll-out-coronavirus-vaccine-continuing-across-east-lothian
story: The Harbours Medical Practice in Cockenzie has completed the vaccination of all patients aged over , which was  people in total.It is now moving on to vaccinating all those aged over , about  people.The surgery has taken a delivery of its second supply of vaccine but it only included  doses, so the process will be slow until the delivery of vaccines increases.The information was shared by Councillor Neil Gilbert at a virtual meeting of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council.GP surgeries across East Lothian are continuing to work on the roll-out of the coronavirus vaccine.In East Lothian, a mass vaccination site is to be located at Queen Margaret University in Musselburgh, when there are enough supplies.At the meeting, Mr Gilbert also said that  per cent of care home residents and staff in the county had now been vaccinated and more should have been completed by the end of last week.Across Scotland, Nicola Sturgeon said that  per cent of care home residents had received their first dose of a coronavirus vaccine.More than  per cent of care home staff and more than  per cent of frontline health workers have also received their first doses.She added that all those aged over , those in care homes and frontline health workers would receive their first dose by the beginning of February.The over-s and extremely vulnerable are due to receive their vaccines by mid-February, the over-s by March, and everyone  on the priority list ndash which includes everyone over  ndash by May.

title: 140-new-homes-built-edge-macmerry
story: Balfour Beatty Homes will build  new homes and  flats on the western edge of the village, with work starting in the coming months.As part of the planning approval, the developer will have to put forward money for ious improvements in nearby infrastructure.Contributions towards improvements at the villagersquos primary school, Tranentrsquos Ross High School, surrounding roads and sporting provision total pound,,..A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoSection  agreements are proportional to the size of any development and, as they are used to improve infrastructure such as any necessary increase in education provision and upgrades or installation of transport links, they are essential in enabling East Lothian Council to ensure development is carried out in a sustainable, controlled way.Discussions surrounding the land to the west and north of the villagersquos Main Street have been ongoing for more than four years.Originally, as many as  homes were ndash pound, ndash goes towards the provision of additional accommodation at Ross High School, with a further pound, going towards Macmerry Primary School.The council will also receive pound,. for an title: access-restricted-gosford-estate-vandalism-incidents
story: The news has alarmed local residents, who have said it would be ldquoterrible to lose access to the private grounds due to the actions of a few.Martin Andrews, factor at Wemyss and March Estates, said: ldquoOver the last few months, we have had doorways kicked in suffered masonry damage to the curling house had damaged slates on the boathouse roof due to people climbing on it lost a bench which was stolen or thrown into the ponds had numerous way markers thrown into the ponds during the recent freeze seen loose sticks or logs thrown into the ponds and had signicant wildle disturbance, especially from dogs out of control.ldquoThere have also been parking altercations which have required police attention on more than one occasion.ldquoWe also wish dog owners would deal with poo bags properly and not dispose of them in our trees and bushes.Mr Andrews said that the number of visitors accessing the estate and policies was higher now than at any time in the past, probably due to Covid- restrictions.He said: ldquoWe have tried hard to keep Gosford open during the Covid pandemic to provide an area where access by the public can be taken safely but are growing increasingly frustrated by the lack of respect for the estate being shown by some.The estate operates an annual permit system which allows holders access to walk in the grounds of Gosford for pound per year.A number of access points into the estate ndash between Longniddry and Aberlady ndash have now been closed off, with visitors directed to enter via the Gosford Bothy Farm Shop.The estate has also employed a ranger on a part-time basis to manage access and check permits.Mr Andrews said that, despite signs around the estate saying lsquoNo cycling in the gardens and grounds of Gosfordrsquo, people were cycling through the woodland tracks to the ponds.He said: ldquoThere has been a signicant increase in all cycling.ldquoWe do have some problems with cycling at Gosford and it is not appropriate to cycle in the gardens.A spokesman for Gullane Area Community Council, who lives in Aberlady, said: ldquoItrsquos probably just kids who are vandalising it.ldquoThese kids have got nothing to do during the day and are just going about inside Gosford. Closing off the grounds at Gosford will have a major impact on [the community] ndash itrsquos something we wouldnrsquot want.ldquoLots of the villagers walk in there and it would be terriblewe lost it.ldquoBut itrsquos their [Gosford Housersquos] prerogative ndash they own the land and itrsquos understandable.ldquoItrsquos something we wouldnrsquot want to lose butthatrsquos how the Gosford people want to run it, itrsquos their problem, and thatrsquos how they want to address it.An East Lothian Council spokesperson confirmed they had been consulted.ldquoIn recent months, the number of visitors accessing outdoor locations across East Lothian has risen considerably, which has put pressure on some of the more fragile environmental sites, said the spokesperson.ldquoThe Scottish Outdoor Access Code is based on three key principles: lsquoTo respect the interests of others care for the environment and to take responsibility for your own actions.rsquoldquoCouncils work closely with landowners and managers to support a balance between providing people with access to the outdoors and ensuring that people are enjoying the outdoors responsibly.ldquoUnfortunately, the number of visitors to the Gosford Estate has resulted in some erosion of footpaths and there have also been some incidents of vandalism which they are managing, after consultation with East Lothian Council, through temporary restricted access.Mr Andrews added: ldquoGosford has been open to the public for a very long time and walking in the grounds and gardens is enjoyed by numerous iniduals and families, the vast majority of whom are supportive and responsible.ldquoIt will be a great shamethe minority continue to lead this debate and we will try very hard to make sure that the grounds remain open for bona fide visitors to continue to enjoy.ldquoWe are trying to manage things in a fair manner and feel that asking people to access via a specic entrance to allow us some ability to engage with visitors and to manage things is reasonable.What do you think  Email your comments, along with your name and address, to editorial@eastlothiancourier for possible inclusion in our letters page

title: covid-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-outlines-supermarket-guidance
story: The First Minister stressed the importance of wearing a face covering properly, as she announced a further  deaths and , positive coronavirus tests had been recorded in the past day.The number of people in hospital has increased by  in  hours to ,, after a sharp drop in the daily figure on Thursday.The Covid- death toll under the daily measure ndash of people who first tested positive for the virus within the previous  days ndash now stands at ,.During her daily coronavirus briefing on Friday, the First Minister said shopping for food is now ldquoone of the few reasons why we should be leaving our homes ndash as she stressed it is not risk-free.What are the rules to follow Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThe new iant is spreading faster and more easily so it is all the more important that when we do go to a shophellip we take the necessary precautions.Ms Sturgeon said: "Firstly, try to limit the number of times that you go shopping right now."If you, in normal times, went shopping two or three times a week, try to limit that to just once a week now.""Where possible, order online, andyou do go to a shop and itrsquos busy, donrsquot go in," the First Minister added."Try somewhere  or decide to go back at a less busy time."Ms Sturgeon continued: "Shop aloneyou can, thatrsquos a really important piece of advice."Donrsquot go with other people. If thatrsquos not possible,you need help with your shopping, try to make sure that you keep the group you are with as small as possible."Bearin mind some retailers are now actually promoting a one shopper one trolley policy to reduce the time spent in shops.""Sanitise your hands when you are going in and leaving a supermarket," Ms Sturgeon added."Most premises will have sanitising stations at entrances, checkouts and exits."She added: "Remember to maintain two-metre distancing at all times, I know how dficult that is when you are trying to get your shopping from the shelves butthere are people standing in front of you, or in front of items that you want, donrsquot lean over them to try to reach those items."When you are queuing, try to remember to keep your distance from the person in front of you."The First Minister continued: "Be patientyou have to wait a bit longer ndash show consideration for shop staff and other customers."She later said: "At all times, follow the FACTS guidance, that includes wearing a face covering."Unless you are exempt for a specic reason, face coverings must be worn in all retail premises ndash and remember, your face covering should be over your mouth and your nose."Thatrsquos really vital to make sure itrsquos giving you the protection that itrsquos designed to do but also that itrsquos giving the people around you maximum protection as well."

title: coronavirus-celtic-players-got-woeful-defence-record-comes-covid
story: Instead of showing a scintilla of contrition, Lennon launched into a fusillade of grievance against the criticisms and hypocrisy of those who lambasted the decision to go ahead with the camp, despite the worsening situation at home. Nobody, from the First Minister to the Scottish Football Association, escaped his wrath. Not even the breaking news that another team member had tested positive derailed his self-righteous fury. Theirs, he said, was an entirely legitimate and well-run exercise. The furore, he said, was ldquoall political.Maybe it was in some quarters, but for the general public ndash those who have never heard of Mo Salah or Harry Kane let alone Scott Brown ndash to see sportsmen heading for the sun at a time of national crisis was astonishing. It starkly reinforced the fact that footballers are an elite for whom the rules are stretched or revised wherever possible. Indeed, the sporting top tier appears to live in a bubble of its own, but not the Covid kind. Just like Novak Djokovic, complaining about having to quarantine in a Melbourne hotel room, these star performers believe they are invincible, that their status and acclaim protects them from criticism, challenge or, indeed, infection.: Vaccinate supermarket staffTo be fair, the scenes of Celtic on their day off by the Dubai poolside were not as shocking as those from the autumn, when the Scottish squad celebrated its Euro  play-off success. In jubilation, they danced a congo like six-year-olds at a party. Since then, viewers of the Premier League have weekly witnessed footage of high-profile players ndash and in Europe ndash cuddling and canoodling after every goal and victory. Despite dire levels of British infection, the idea of taking a firebreak pause this season was deemed unthinkable.Celticrsquos miscalculation was to jet off just at the point when everyone  had to hunker down. Their trip might not technically have broken any law, but nor did it uphold the spirit of the times. While they were enjoying sunshine on their backs, ordinary mortals were facing a grim endurance test, and hospitals filling with the sick and dying. As Nicola Sturgeon has repeatedly urged, testing the limit of whatrsquos allowable is in nobodyrsquos interests. We should be trying to do as little as possible, not as much. Heading to Dubai certainly falls into the category of pushing the envelope, as does much of the sportrsquos behaviour in recent weeks.Lennonrsquos lack of remorse is not surprising. Across the board there is a sense of entitlement about the football world. It is treated so reverentially yoursquod be forgiven for assuming it was sacred. While other industries and activities are mothballed until the pandemic is under control, football has been designated a special case. Getting the game back on the pitch has been viewed as an urgent priority, asthe countryrsquos mental health depends upon it. The mere thought of a match makes everyone happy, or so we are told, although clearly that is nonsense. Where I live, Scotland could be playing in the World Cup final, yet few would be glued to their screens. Rugby is an entirely dferent matter, streets empty during the Calcutta Cup.So when did football become a barometer of national well-being  To a degree all sport is for the wider good, but nothing beats football for the privilege and leeway allowed, in the name of boosting morale. It seems to be universally accepted that without the chance to cheer on their side, fans would go bonkers with boredom and misery. While some see the vaccine as light at end of the tunnel, for a clubrsquos supporters, watching their side emerge from the tunnel is the stuff of miracles.I admit, it does feel like a semblance of normality to hear match commentaries on the radio on a Saturday afternoon. For the first half hour I even enjoyed the David and Goliath clash that was Marine v Spurs. Yet while top players are meant to be role models for young men in respect of Covid etiquette, many set a poor example. Spitting, neglecting to mask up, bouncing like popcorn in cramped changing rooms, holding parties, inviting young women into their hotel rooms... the list goes on. Despite all the advantages and privileges football has been accorded during lockdown, still the players ndash and managers ndash donrsquot get it. With notable exceptions such as Marcus Rashford, they are like royalty of old, heedless of what regular people are going through.: We can all enjoy Scotlands hillsBy comparison, how do small theatre companies or arts bodies feel ndash not to mention musicians, writers and artists ndash to see football clubs asking for government support  In one breath they beg for a handout, while with the next they bid millions for new players. Meanwhile, other players earning tens of thousands of pounds each week sit idle on the bench, like thoroughbreds confined to the stable.Despite the rise in the womenrsquos game, and a growing number of female fans, football remains a minority and mainly male interest. Almost as many folk attend church as games. Going to the cinema or theatre, listening to live country, blues or classical music or poetry readings, are minority interests too. All of these and countless other art forms and activities are as vital to our sanity as the sight of a penalty shootout.In Scotland, the so-called beautul game is a boring two-horse race: Rangers v Celtic . As Celtic might eventually learn, own goals come in many forms. Few, however, are more self-defeating than when the sporting elite loses touch with the real world.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions They do not necessarily represent the views of the Herald.

Cornwall with Simon Reeve, which aired in November last year, was a fascinating investigation into the future of the county as it emerged from the first UK lockdown.And now therersquos a new, four-part BBC Two series in which the -year-old presenter and author takes a look back at some of the most remote destinations he has visited ndash from Arctic glaciers to tropical reefs ndash while reflecting on what he has learned from his extraordinary travels.what was REACTION TO CORNWALL WITH SIMON REEVE It was slightly overwhelmingly brilliant, to be honest. I think people felt that it painted a more accurate picture of Cornwall than a lot of the programmes that are filmed there.YOU VIDEO CALL JAHANGIR, WHO YOU MET AS A -YEAR-OLD IN BANGLADESH IN ...I had a right old sob about little Jahangir ndash now Jahangir the dad, whorsquos building a new and better le for his family.Knowing what had happened to him was very powerful, and seeing and hearing what hersquos doing was even more intense, both for me and for Jonathan, who was the cameraman who filmed me for this Incredible Journeys series, but he also filmed me with that lad Jahangir more than  years ago in Bangladesh in that glass factory.YOU ALSO OPEN UP ABOUT YOUR PERSONAL STRUGGLES I think itrsquos always been good when anyone whorsquos had a tiny modicum of success opens up about their luck and their dficulties.HOW DO YOU THINK SHARING YOUR STORY WILL HELP PEOPLE I think there is merit to people knowing, at a time when wersquore a very unequal country, that my background was more lsquonormalrsquo ndashyou want to put it that way ndash than most. I managed to leave school with basically no qualications and went on the dole and was in serious risk of falling into long-term unemployment and welfare dependency, and drugs and everything  that you can get when yoursquore a slightly lost lad growing up on the edge of inner-city London. And I was lucky!And what I hope partly, I suppose, is that it helps people to be a little bit more understanding of those who slip off the path, and deserve help and guidance to find their way back on.ARE PEOPLE SURPRISED TO HEAR YOUR HISTORY Well, I suppose therersquos a bit of an assumption that people naturally make that some bod on the telly who goes off on these journeys is going to be yet another public school-educated bloke from a connected family. And that is not my background at all.It did wind me up a little bit because sometimes people would say it overtly. I would meet them, and therersquod be this bristle because they thought I was from a particular background. But Irsquod just say a few things that humanised me a bit more and made them realise I wasnrsquot a toff.Incredible Journeys with Simon Reeve, BBC Two, Sunday, pm

title: film-new-adaptation-blithe-spirit-dappled-sentiments-bygone-era
story: Dappled with sentiments from a bygone era, its precisely the situation in which Noel Cowards classic comedy Blithe Spirit finds itself.Directed by Edward Hall, whose previous credits include hit ITV series Downton Abbey and acclaimed BBC drama Spooks, the script centres on wildly successful yet assuredly unhinged crime novelist Charles Condomine, played by fellow Downton Abbey alumnus Dan Stevens.Set in , the light-hearted tale unravels within the Art Deco confines of the writers sprawling Surrey home which he shares with current we Ruth, played by Now You See Me star Isla Fisher.Edging towards insanity, a tweed-clad Charles desperately searches for the inspiration that has been absent since the passing of his first we, Elvira, played by Knocked Ups Leslie Mann.That is until an enthralling evening at the theatre captures Charles imagination, resulting in the shows star - a famous medium named Madame Arcati, brought to le by Skyfalls Dame Judi Dench - travelling to conduct a private seance in their home."I think its interesting to remember that this play was written in , where Britain was facing a pretty bleak time and Coward had a peculiarly British ability to find comedy and wit and humour and levity in some pretty bleak subject matter," notes Stevens, ."Essentially, my character is a grieving alcoholic at the end of his tether, struggling with writers block and, you know, hes not in a great way."Yet, Coward finds this absolutely mad triangle and, you know, its just glorious chaos really. I think, you know, its quite nice to remember that in the midst of all the bleakness."A combination of physical comedy and an altogether softer approach to Cowards original sharp, quick-witted exchanges, the film sees Madame Arcati conjure the spirit of Charles first we, Elvira, resulting in an ensuing love triangle from beyond the grave."Youve got a group of us really sat around essentially watching Judi do her thing - we have a couple of interjections, but its really the Madame Arcati show at that moment, quite literally," adds Stevens of shooting the films seance scenes."There are all sorts of effects going on and its a long old scene."But great fun, you know. Just a very silly gang, sat around a table with Judi Dench doing her incredible work, its a pretty great day at the office."First opening in the West End in , the original production was subsequently transferred to the big screen courtesy of David Lean and his  adaptation.By todays standards, the premise of two wives quarrelling over their husband might be considered a little outdated as a concept.However, the script boasts a warm and nostalgic undercurrent which, paired with the films period setting, provides some suitably comedic respite in the midst of an otherwise bleak January."It had all the right notes that made me want to do it, really," says Stevens."And also, it was my first time trying to do Coward on screen, which not a lot of people have tried to do to be honest and it hasnt always been done successfully."There was a lovely circularity to this project, in that my first West End job was in Noel Cowards Hay Fever with Judi Dench, directed by Sir Peter Hall."I started out in his theatre company and its his son, Ed Hall, who came to me with this really lovely adaptation."As the tit-for-tat storyline unravels, Charles current we, Ruth, finds herself increasingly jealous of Elvira, a woman only her husband can see.Equal parts talented and manipulative, Manns ghostly character is something of a wind-up merchant when it comes to subtly taunting her living counterpart - a trait that captured the attention of Mann from the outset."I was thrilled to be asked to join in - I was asked kind of late in the game, I think someone  dropped out," laughs Mann, ."To be able to completely let loose and be this big character - Ive never done that before."To just carry myself the way that she carries herself. Ed Hall had the whole movie in his head, exactly how he wanted to shoot it and wanted it to be and I just kind of followed what his vision was."Stepping into the role alongside acting icon Dame Judi, Mann admits to being a little intimidated by the whole endeavour."Shes a national treasure," declares Mann, "shes the funniest, shes the warmest, shes the best."I shared a dressing room with her - well, it was one room separated by this paper partition thing, so I can hear everything - [and] because I was alone in my room and she was always with someone talking, I guess I was eavesdropping on what she was saying."She would have been more than happy to talk about things, Im sure. But I was so intimidated by her, I didnt feel - I didnt want to bother her. I dont know why she would want to waste her time talking to me  So thats why I eavesdrop."I would just lay on my couch and listen, listen to her beautul, melodic voice."Not in a creepy way! I just couldnt not hear because I was alone and so, I guess I was listening in on everything Judi Dench was talking about."Shes going to think Im such a creep!"Blithe Spirit is available to watch now on Sky Cinema.

title: portfolio-burns-night-fife-arms-sim-canetty-clark
story: Gallery owners Iwan and Manuela Wirth first visited Braemar in  and fell in love with the landscape. In , they purchased the Fe Arms with the ambition of restoring the Victorian-era hotel to its former glory. They spent five years transforming it into a luxury destination, commissioning Scottish artisans and craftspeople to work on its interiors and bringing artworks from their collection to cover the walls.The restoration is chronicled in a new book published by Phaidon, from which this image is taken.ldquoThe Fe Arms is a world enclosed, the Wirths suggest in the introduction. ldquoIt is a place to get lost indoors ndash in the thousands of art objects and natural specimens, the delicious food that changes with the seasons, the sumptuous but playfully designed bed chambers, and the lively fireside and barstool conversations that are as long and beguiling as the walks for which Scots are duly famed.Taken from The Fe Arms, published by Phaidon, priced pound.
